data_findings.finding: This is a 2D packing optimization problem: pack Christmas tree toys (irregular polygons) into smallest square bounding box for N=1 to 200 trees. Score = sum of (side_length^2 / N) for all N. Lower is better.
Tree geometry: 15-vertex polygon with trunk (0.15w x 0.2h), base tier (0.7w), mid tier (0.4w), top tier (0.25w), tip at y=0.8. Trees can be rotated and positioned at (x, y, deg).

Key technique: bbox3 C++ optimizer - uses simulated annealing with complex number vector coordination, fluid dynamics, hinge pivot, density gradient flow, and global boundary tension. Runs in phases with increasing timeout.

Key technique: fix_direction - rotation tightening using scipy.optimize.minimize_scalar to find optimal rotation angle (0-90 deg) that minimizes bounding box side length. Uses convex hull of all tree points.
Key technique: Backward propagation - for N=200 down to N=2, try removing boundary-touching trees and check if resulting (N-1) configuration is better than current best for that N.

Key technique: Greedy tree placement - start from center, place trees at random weighted angles (weighted by |sin(2*angle)| for corner preference), move inward until collision, back up until no overlap.
Key technique: Overlap repair - when optimizer creates overlaps, replace invalid N-configurations with donor configurations from a known-good baseline CSV.
